top_comment.text:
Großostheim? Ist mir nur bekannt als Hauptsitz von Nintendo in Europa. Das 
weiß ich natürlich, weil die Anschrift auf den Spielerückseiten der 
Nintendospiele steht. Leider ist die Schließung dieses Standorts 
bekanntgegeben worden D:﻿
top_comment.author: energiehonse

comments.text:
+rewboss +energiehonse +protapirus  "Großfrostheim" sage ich nur. Leider 
sind die weggezogen.
comments.author: derLPMaxe - Generischer Name, Generischer Kanal.

comments.text:
Ja genau. Die deutschen Versionen von manchen Videospielen von Nintendo 
haben deswegen versteckte Anspielungen auf Großostheim.
comments.author: rewboss

comments.text: Ja, da musste ich auch als erstes dran denken :D
comments.author: protapirus

top_comment.text: A mini-Oktoberfest, for those who find Munich hellish.﻿
top_comment.author: rewboss

comments.text:
+Seegal Galguntijak you are not right. Long time ago, the people in Munich 
want to have a "Volksfest" but intime it is a Drunkfest. 😀😀😀
comments.author: Marcel Haas

comments.text:
This is even better than the Oktoberfest in Munich. Or do they show these 
old arts and crafts in Munich? I don't think so. Munich has become a fest 
just to become drunk, not to see rare things (unless you count the sheer 
amount of drunk people as a rarity).
comments.author: Seegal Galguntijak

captions.text:
Großostheim can trace its history back
as far as the 8th century.

The remains of the town’s defences,
mostly dismantled in the 19th century,

are old by our standards,
but young compared to the town itself.

Even the oldest surviving houses
surrounding the market place

were built when the town
was already 800 years old.

The Church of St Peter and St Paul
was originally built in 1250,
but added to and altered in the centuries since.

One of its most precious possessions
is an altar by Tilman Riemenschneider,

one of the most prolific sculptors
of the 16th century,

a master of both stone and wood
who lived and worked in the area.
Even older by about 100 years is this mural.

But what brought us here
was the Market Place Festival,
although we could have wished for better weather.

One of the organisers was a local brewery,
making this, in a sense, a beer festival.

In the Middle Ages, beer, unlike water,
was pretty much germ-free,

and had enough calories
to be a useful supplement to the diet,
which is why it became so important.

A Märzen, the traditional beer for an autumn
festival, was brewed specially for this one,

and bottled with the world’s smallest
antique beer-bottling machine —
which is about 100 years old.
It’s not just beer that’s celebrated here.

Other traditional arts and crafts
were on show as well,

providing a hands-on experience of some
aspects of life in centuries gone by.
